episode_summary: This episode of "No Such Thing As A Fish" covers a variety of intriguing topics, including a mysterious donut hole measurer from the 1940s, the use of ancient poetry to track porpoise habitats, the unconventional use of beet juice in Canadian tractor tires, and a library in San Francisco designed to help rebuild civilization in the event of an apocalypse.

facts.fact: In the 1940s, a mystery man traveled America measuring the holes in donuts and passing a ruling on what size they should be.
Scientists are using poetry from the past to protect porpoises.
In Canada, tractor tires are filled up with vegetable juice.
If civilization comes to an end, one of the best places to be is a cafe in Fort Mason, San Francisco.
